name: What is in a Name? Part 1 Quiz | Name Game | 10 Questions

questions.text: This Roman emperor was the adopted son of Claudius. He assumed Claudius' middle name, probably at the advice of his mother, Agrippina. What was his real name?
questions.explanation:
Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus.

	This man later became known as Nero..and his adopted father and his mother didn't fare very well. Claudius was poisoned by either Nero or Agrippina...and Agrippina was executed by her loving son.

questions.text: This author borrowed the name of a Finnish writer for her first name and assumed the name of her typewriter for the last. What is her real name?
questions.explanation:
Alisa Rosenbaum.

	This is Ayn Rand. The typewriter was the Remington-Rand. She worked in the wardrobe department of RKO studios until Cecil DeMille took her under his wing.

questions.text: Called upon to rule his people at age 13, the name by which he later became known means 'greatest of rulers, emperor of all men'. What is his real name?
questions.explanation:
Temujin.

	This is Genghis Khan. When he was born his father had just slain an enemy by the name of 'Temujin', so in his triumph he chose that name for his son.

questions.text: This short story writer used a pen name taken from 'The Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam'. What is his real name?
questions.explanation:
H.H. Munro

	This is Saki. Born in Scotland, he was killed in World War I while serving as a volunteer.

questions.text: This sixteenth century Venetian painter based his professional name on the profession of his father. What was his real name?
questions.explanation:
Jacopo Robusti.

	This is Tintoretto, which means 'little dyer'. Not very much is known of him, except he was unpopular among colleagues for his at-times unscrupulous methods of procuring commissions.

questions.text: This short story writer took his nom de plume from the name of one of his prison guards. What is his real name?
questions.explanation:
William Sydney Porter.

	This is O. Henry (he was in prison for embezzling).

questions.text: This philosopher's professional name is rumored to have been given to him by his wrestling coach and was a comment on the rather broad expanse of his brow. What is his real name?
questions.explanation:
Aristocles.

	This is Plato. The broadness might also have referred to his shoulders or the breadth of his knowledge...but I sort of like the forehead story.

questions.text: This Roman emperor's name was a nickname given to him as a boy when he would wear miniature versions of military boots. What is his real name?
questions.explanation:
Caius Caesar Germanicus.

	This is Caligula. His name means 'little boots'.

questions.text: This author's pen name was derived from Jules Sandeau, who was instrumental in furthering her career. What is her real name?
questions.explanation:
Amantine Dupin.

	This is George Sand. Amantine Dupin was the Baroness Dudevant.

questions.text: This author's pen name was the nickname of his youngest brother. His works were often accompanied by the sketches of Hablot Knight Browne, who adopted the name 'Phiz' because of its similar sound. What was this author's real name?
questions.explanation:
Charles Dickens & charles dickens.

	Browne provided the illustrations for 'David Copperfield', 'Martin Chuzzlewit' and 'Bleak House'. Dickens' previous illustrator, Robert Seymour, committed suicide shortly after providing the illustrations for 'Pickwick Papers'.
